trans-unit.target: Properties

trans-unit.source: .NET, .NET Core
trans-unit.target: .NET, .NET Core

trans-unit.source: Properties
trans-unit.target: Properties

trans-unit.source: Properties are first class citizens in C#.
trans-unit.target: Properties are first class citizens in C#.

trans-unit.source: The language defines syntax that enables developers to write code that accurately expresses their design intent.
trans-unit.target: The language defines syntax that enables developers to write code that accurately expresses their design intent.

trans-unit.source: Properties behave like fields when they are accessed.
trans-unit.target: Properties behave like fields when they are accessed.

trans-unit.source: However, unlike fields, properties are implemented with accessors that define the statements executed when a property is accessed or assigned.
trans-unit.target: However, unlike fields, properties are implemented with accessors that define the statements executed when a property is accessed or assigned.

trans-unit.source: Property Syntax
trans-unit.target: Property Syntax

trans-unit.source: The syntax for properties is a natural extension to fields.
trans-unit.target: The syntax for properties is a natural extension to fields.

trans-unit.source: A field defines a storage location:
trans-unit.target: A field defines a storage location:

trans-unit.source: A property definition contains declarations for a `get` and `set` accessor that retrieves and assigns the value of that property:
trans-unit.target: A property definition contains declarations for a `get` and `set` accessor that retrieves and assigns the value of that property:

trans-unit.source: The syntax shown above is the *auto property* syntax.
trans-unit.target: The syntax shown above is the *auto property* syntax.

trans-unit.source: The compiler generates the storage location for the field that backs up the property.
trans-unit.target: The compiler generates the storage location for the field that backs up the property.

trans-unit.source: The compiler also implements the body of the `get` and `set` accessors.
trans-unit.target: The compiler also implements the body of the `get` and `set` accessors.

trans-unit.source: You can also define the storage yourself, as shown below:
trans-unit.target: You can also define the storage yourself, as shown below:

trans-unit.source: The property definition shown above is a read-write property.
trans-unit.target: The property definition shown above is a read-write property.

trans-unit.source: Notice the keyword `value` in the set accessor.
trans-unit.target: Notice the keyword `value` in the set accessor.

trans-unit.source: The `set` accessor always has a single parameter named `value`.
trans-unit.target: The `set` accessor always has a single parameter named `value`.

trans-unit.source: The `get` accessor must return a value that is convertible to the type of the property (`string` in this example).
trans-unit.target: The `get` accessor must return a value that is convertible to the type of the property (`string` in this example).

trans-unit.source: That's the basics of the syntax.
trans-unit.target: That's the basics of the syntax.

trans-unit.source: There are many different variations that support a variety of different design idioms.
trans-unit.target: There are many different variations that support a variety of different design idioms.

trans-unit.source: Let's explore those, and learn the syntax options for each.
trans-unit.target: Let's explore those, and learn the syntax options for each.

trans-unit.source: Scenarios
trans-unit.target: Scenarios

trans-unit.source: The examples above showed one of the simplest cases of property definition: a read-write property with no validation.
trans-unit.target: The examples above showed one of the simplest cases of property definition: a read-write property with no validation.

trans-unit.source: By writing the code you want in the `get` and `set` accessors, you can create many different scenarios.
trans-unit.target: By writing the code you want in the `get` and `set` accessors, you can create many different scenarios.

trans-unit.source: Validation
trans-unit.target: Validation

trans-unit.source: You can write code in the `set` accessor to ensure that the values represented by a property are always valid.
trans-unit.target: You can write code in the `set` accessor to ensure that the values represented by a property are always valid.

trans-unit.source: For example, suppose one rule for the `Person` class is that the name cannot be blank, or whitespace.
trans-unit.target: For example, suppose one rule for the `Person` class is that the name cannot be blank, or whitespace.

trans-unit.source: You would write that as follows:
trans-unit.target: You would write that as follows:

trans-unit.source: The example above enforces the rule that the first name must not be blank, or whitespace.
trans-unit.target: The example above enforces the rule that the first name must not be blank, or whitespace.

trans-unit.source: If a developer writes
trans-unit.target: If a developer writes

trans-unit.source: That assignment throws an `ArgumentException`.
trans-unit.target: That assignment throws an `ArgumentException`.

trans-unit.source: Because a property set accessor must have a void return type, you report errors in the set accessor by throwing an exception.
trans-unit.target: Because a property set accessor must have a void return type, you report errors in the set accessor by throwing an exception.

trans-unit.source: That is a simple case of validation.
trans-unit.target: That is a simple case of validation.

trans-unit.source: You can extend this same syntax to anything needed in your scenario.
trans-unit.target: You can extend this same syntax to anything needed in your scenario.

trans-unit.source: You can check the relationships between different properties, or validate against any external conditions.
trans-unit.target: You can check the relationships between different properties, or validate against any external conditions.

trans-unit.source: Any valid C# statements are valid in a property accessor.
trans-unit.target: Any valid C# statements are valid in a property accessor.

trans-unit.source: Read-only
trans-unit.target: Read-only

trans-unit.source: Up to this point, all the property definitions you have seen are read/write properties with public accessors.
trans-unit.target: Up to this point, all the property definitions you have seen are read/write properties with public accessors.

trans-unit.source: That's not the only valid accessibility for properties.
trans-unit.target: That's not the only valid accessibility for properties.

trans-unit.source: You can create read-only properties, or give different accessibility to the set and get accessors.
trans-unit.target: You can create read-only properties, or give different accessibility to the set and get accessors.

trans-unit.source: Suppose that your `Person` class should only enable changing the value of the `FirstName` property from other methods in that class.
trans-unit.target: Suppose that your `Person` class should only enable changing the value of the `FirstName` property from other methods in that class.

trans-unit.source: You could give the set accessor `private` accessibility instead of `public`:
trans-unit.target: You could give the set accessor `private` accessibility instead of `public`:

trans-unit.source: Now, the `FirstName` property can be accessed from any code, but it can only be assigned from other code in the `Person` class.
trans-unit.target: Now, the `FirstName` property can be accessed from any code, but it can only be assigned from other code in the `Person` class.

trans-unit.source: You can add any restrictive access modifier to either the set or get accessors.
trans-unit.target: You can add any restrictive access modifier to either the set or get accessors.

trans-unit.source: Any access modifier you place on the individual accessor must be more limited than the access modifier on the property definition.
trans-unit.target: Any access modifier you place on the individual accessor must be more limited than the access modifier on the property definition.

trans-unit.source: The above is legal because the `FirstName` property is `public`, but the set accessor is `private`.
trans-unit.target: The above is legal because the `FirstName` property is `public`, but the set accessor is `private`.

trans-unit.source: You could not declare a `private` property with a `public` accessor.
trans-unit.target: You could not declare a `private` property with a `public` accessor.

trans-unit.source: Property declarations can also be declared `protected`, `internal`, `protected internal` or even `private`.
trans-unit.target: Property declarations can also be declared `protected`, `internal`, `protected internal` or even `private`.

trans-unit.source: It is also legal to place the more restrictive modifier on the `get` accessor.
trans-unit.target: It is also legal to place the more restrictive modifier on the `get` accessor.

trans-unit.source: For example, you could have a `public` property, but restrict the `get` accessor to `private`.
trans-unit.target: For example, you could have a `public` property, but restrict the `get` accessor to `private`.

trans-unit.source: That scenario is rarely done in practice.
trans-unit.target: That scenario is rarely done in practice.

trans-unit.source: Computed Properties
trans-unit.target: Computed Properties

trans-unit.source: A property does not need to simply return the value of a member field.
trans-unit.target: A property does not need to simply return the value of a member field.

trans-unit.source: You can create properties that return a computed value.
trans-unit.target: You can create properties that return a computed value.

trans-unit.source: Let's expand the `Person` object to return the full name, computed by concatenating the first and last names:
trans-unit.target: Let's expand the `Person` object to return the full name, computed by concatenating the first and last names:

trans-unit.source: The example above uses the *String Interpolation* syntax to create the formatted string for the full name.
trans-unit.target: The example above uses the *String Interpolation* syntax to create the formatted string for the full name.

trans-unit.source: You can also use *Expression Bodied Members*, which provides a more succinct way to create the computed `FullName` property:
trans-unit.target: You can also use *Expression Bodied Members*, which provides a more succinct way to create the computed `FullName` property:

trans-unit.source: *Expression Bodied Members* use the *lambda expression* syntax to define a method that contain a single expression.
trans-unit.target: *Expression Bodied Members* use the *lambda expression* syntax to define a method that contain a single expression.

trans-unit.source: Here, that expression returns the full name for the person object.
trans-unit.target: Here, that expression returns the full name for the person object.

trans-unit.source: Lazy Evaluated Properties
trans-unit.target: Lazy Evaluated Properties

trans-unit.source: You can mix the concept of a computed property with storage and create a *lazy evaluated property*.
trans-unit.target: You can mix the concept of a computed property with storage and create a *lazy evaluated property*.

trans-unit.source: For example, you could update the `FullName` property so that the string formatting only happened the first time it was accessed:
trans-unit.target: For example, you could update the `FullName` property so that the string formatting only happened the first time it was accessed:

trans-unit.source: The above code contains a bug though.
trans-unit.target: The above code contains a bug though.

trans-unit.source: If code updates the value of either the `FirstName` or `LastName` property, the previously evaluated `fullName` field is invalid.
trans-unit.target: If code updates the value of either the `FirstName` or `LastName` property, the previously evaluated `fullName` field is invalid.

trans-unit.source: You need to update the `set` accessors of the `FirstName` and `LastName` property so that the `fullName` field is calculated again:
trans-unit.target: You need to update the `set` accessors of the `FirstName` and `LastName` property so that the `fullName` field is calculated again:

trans-unit.source: This final version evaluates the `FullName` property only when needed.
trans-unit.target: This final version evaluates the `FullName` property only when needed.

trans-unit.source: If the previously calculated version is valid, it's used.
trans-unit.target: If the previously calculated version is valid, it's used.

trans-unit.source: If another state change invalidates the previously calculated version, it will be recalculated.
trans-unit.target: If another state change invalidates the previously calculated version, it will be recalculated.

trans-unit.source: Developers that use this class do not need to know the details of the implementation.
trans-unit.target: Developers that use this class do not need to know the details of the implementation.

trans-unit.source: None of these internal changes affect the use of the Person object.
trans-unit.target: None of these internal changes affect the use of the Person object.

trans-unit.source: That's the key reason for using Properties to expose data members of an object.
trans-unit.target: That's the key reason for using Properties to expose data members of an object.

trans-unit.source: INotifyPropertyChanged
trans-unit.target: INotifyPropertyChanged

trans-unit.source: A final scenario where you need to write code in a property accessor is to support the `INotifyPropertyChanged` interface used to notify data binding clients that a value has changed.
trans-unit.target: A final scenario where you need to write code in a property accessor is to support the `INotifyPropertyChanged` interface used to notify data binding clients that a value has changed.

trans-unit.source: When the value of a property changes, the object raises the `PropertyChanged` event to indicate the change.
trans-unit.target: When the value of a property changes, the object raises the `PropertyChanged` event to indicate the change.

trans-unit.source: The data binding libraries, in turn, update display elements based on that change.
trans-unit.target: The data binding libraries, in turn, update display elements based on that change.

trans-unit.source: The code below shows how you would implement `INotifyPropertyChanged` for the `FirstName` property of this person class.
trans-unit.target: The code below shows how you would implement `INotifyPropertyChanged` for the `FirstName` property of this person class.

trans-unit.source: The `?.` operator is called the *null conditional operator*.
trans-unit.target: The `?.` operator is called the *null conditional operator*.

trans-unit.source: It checks for a null reference before evaluating the right side of the operator.
trans-unit.target: It checks for a null reference before evaluating the right side of the operator.

trans-unit.source: The end result is that if there are no subscribers to the `PropertyChanged` event, the code to raise the event doesn't execute.
trans-unit.target: The end result is that if there are no subscribers to the `PropertyChanged` event, the code to raise the event doesn't execute.

trans-unit.source: It would throw a `NullReferenceException` without this check in that case.
trans-unit.target: It would throw a `NullReferenceException` without this check in that case.

trans-unit.source: See the page on [`events`](delegates-events.md) for more details.
trans-unit.target: See the page on [`events`](delegates-events.md) for more details.

trans-unit.source: This example also uses the new `nameof` operator to convert from the property name symbol to its text representation.
trans-unit.target: This example also uses the new `nameof` operator to convert from the property name symbol to its text representation.

trans-unit.source: Using `nameof` can reduce errors where you have mistyped the name of the property.
trans-unit.target: Using `nameof` can reduce errors where you have mistyped the name of the property.

trans-unit.source: Again, this is an example of a case where you can write code in your accessors to support the scenarios you need.
trans-unit.target: Again, this is an example of a case where you can write code in your accessors to support the scenarios you need.

trans-unit.source: Summing up
trans-unit.target: Summing up

trans-unit.source: Properties are a form of smart fields in a class or object.
trans-unit.target: Properties are a form of smart fields in a class or object.

trans-unit.source: From outside the object, they appear like fields in the object.
trans-unit.target: From outside the object, they appear like fields in the object.

trans-unit.source: However, properties can be implemented using the full palette of C# functionality.
trans-unit.target: However, properties can be implemented using the full palette of C# functionality.

trans-unit.source: You can provide validation, different accessibility, lazy evaluation, or any requirements your scenarios need.
trans-unit.target: You can provide validation, different accessibility, lazy evaluation, or any requirements your scenarios need.
